prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: XMM_highz_ULIRGs
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: all high redshift (1.0<z<1.7) ULIRG (>1e12 Lsol) BCGs in the XMM field

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Since we only aim to detect continuum emission, we select the single continuum spectral setup and use the TDM correlator in all 4 spectral windows. We group all z>1 ULIRG BCGs in the XMM field in this science goal to make effienct use of time, as they all require the same rms and resolution.

We aim for 0.4" resolution imaging, corresponding to a maximum recoverable scale of ~4.2" in Band 6. This is sufficiently large to avoid resolving out emission (4.2" corresponds to ~35kpc at z=1 which is the lowest redshift in this science goal), while fine enough to unambiguously identify the source(s) of the emission. High 0.4" resolution imaging will achieve an astrometric accuracy of ~0.02", which is crucial for pinpointing the IR emission. At z~1.35, this corresponds to a linear scale 3.5kpc, which will furthermore be appropriate for identifying small clumps in the IR emission, approximately matched in resolution to the in-hand HST data.

We fit the 24um emission identified with each BCG to a Chary and Elbaz (2001) SED to estimate the flux at 230GHz. We expect a flux of > 0.5mJy for the ULIRG (>1e12 Lsol) population. This flux is interpolated from the best fit SED and corresponds to the lowest flux of all the BCGs within the ULIRG sample. We require a S/N of 20 to ensure significant detections in cases where the emission emanates from multiple sources (e.g., 5sigma detections of 4 equally bright sources). We therefore require a rms of corresponding to rms depths of 0.025 mJy at 230GHz.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: XMM_lowz_ULIRGs
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: all low redshift (0.6<z<1.0) ULIRG (>1e12 Lsol) BCGs in the XMM field

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Since we only aim to detect continuum emission, we select the single continuum spectral setup and use the TDM correlator in all 4 spectral windows. We group all z<1 ULIRG BCGs in the XMM field in this science goal to make effienct use of time, as they all require the same rms and resolution.
To match the linear scale in the high and low redshift bins, we downgrade from 0.4" to 0.45" resolution imaging in the lower redshift bin.

We fit the 24um emission identified with each BCG to a Chary and Elbaz (2001) SED to estimate the flux at 230GHz. We expect a flux of > 0.5mJy for the ULIRG (>1e12 Lsol) population. This flux is interpolated from the best fit SED and corresponds to the lowest flux of all the BCGs within the ULIRG sample. We require a S/N of 20 to ensure significant detections in cases where the emission emanates from multiple sources (e.g., 5sigma detections of 4 equally bright sources). We therefore require a rms of corresponding to rms depths of 0.025 mJy at 230GHz.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: XMM_lowz_LIRGs
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: all low redshift (0.6<z<1.0) LIRG (7e11 - 1e12 Lsol) BCGs in the XMM field

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Since we only aim to detect continuum emission, we select the single continuum spectral setup and use the TDM correlator in all 4 spectral windows. We group all z<1 LIRG BCGs in the XMM field in this science goal to make effienct use of time, as they all require the same rms and resolution.
To match the linear scale in the high and low redshift bins, we downgrade from 0.4" to 0.45" resolution imaging in the lower redshift bin.

We fit the 24um emission identified with each BCG to a Chary and Elbaz (2001) SED to estimate the flux at 230GHz. We expect a flux of > 0.4mJy for the LIRG (>7e11 Lsol) population. This flux is interpolated from the best fit SED and corresponds to the lowest flux of all the BCGs within the LIRG sample. We require a S/N of 20 to ensure significant detections in cases where the emission emanates from multiple sources (e.g., 5sigma detections of 4 equally bright sources). We therefore require a rms of corresponding to rms depths of 0.02 mJy at 230GHz.

We fit the 24um emission identified with each BCG to a Chary and Elbaz (2001) SED to estimate the flux at 230GHz. We expect a flux of > 0.5mJy for the ULIRG (>1e12 Lsol) population. This flux is interpolated from the best fit SED and corresponds to the lowest flux of all the BCGs within the ULIRG sample. We therefore require a rms of corresponding to rms depths of 0.025 mJy at 230GHz.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CDFS_lowz_LIRGs
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: all low redshift (0.6<z<1.0) LIRG (7e11 - 1e12 Lsol) BCGs in the CDFS field

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Since we only aim to detect continuum emission, we select the single continuum spectral setup and use the TDM correlator in all 4 spectral windows. We group all z<1 LIRG BCGs in the XMM field in this science goal to make effienct use of time, as they all require the same rms and resolution.
To match the linear scale in the high and low redshift bins, we downgrade from 0.4" to 0.45" resolution imaging in the lower redshift bin.

We fit the 24um emission identified with each BCG to a Chary and Elbaz (2001) SED to estimate the flux at 230GHz. We expect a flux of > 0.4mJy for the LIRG (>7e11 Lsol) population. This flux is interpolated from the best fit SED and corresponds to the lowest flux of all the BCGs within the LIRG sample. We therefore require a rms of corresponding to rms depths of 0.02 mJy at 230GHz.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose high-resolution Band 6 imaging for a statistical study of 20 infrared-detected Brightest Cluster Galaxies (BCGs) within rich SpARCS clusters, spanning over 4 Gyr, from 0.6<z<1.7. With two redshift bins, matched to an infrared luminosity depth based on the evolution of the luminosity function, we will investigate the physical processes driving the high infrared emission emanating from the centers of these clusters as a function of time. We have already discovered a complex of dusty star formation within the core of a z=1.7 cluster --- only with high-resolution HST imaging was this eventually revealed to be a long tidal tail of gas-rich clumps emerging from the BCG halo. It thus seems likely that wet mergers might be an alternative method for BCG growth to the standard dry theory, at least at higher redshifts. High-resolution submillimeter imaging with ALMA is crucial to pinpoint the source of infrared emission and determine whether this mode of BCG assembly is viable at high redshift.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
